textClass.keywords: Coral Immunity Symbiosis Complement C3 Mannose binding lectin Acropora millepora

abstract.p: Reef-building corals are representatives of one of the earliest diverging metazoan lineages and are experiencing increases in bleaching events (breakdown of the coral-Symbiodinium symbiosis) and disease outbreaks. The present study investigates the roles of two pattern recognition proteins, the mannose binding lectin Millectin and a complement factor C3-like protein (C3-Am), in the coral Acropora millepora. The results indicate that the innate immune functions of these molecules are conserved and arose early in evolution. C3-Am is expressed in response to injury, and may function as an opsonin. In contrast, Millectin expression is up-regulated in response to lipopolysaccharide and peptidoglycan. These observations, coupled with localization of Millectin in nematocysts in epidermal tissue, and reported binding of pathogens, are consistent with a key role for the lectin in innate immunity. Furthermore, Millectin was consistently detected binding to the symbiont Symbiodinium in vivo, indicating that the Millectin function of recognition and binding of non-self-entities may have been co-opted from an ancient innate immune system into a role in symbiosis.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Reef-building corals are phylogenetically basal metazoans and are the major architects of coral reefs. The coral holobiont is an obligate association between the coral animal and its dinoflagellate endosymbiont, but this association is delicately balanced and coral reefs worldwide are increasingly threatened by mass coral bleaching events (breakdown of coral-dinoflagellate symbiosis) and outbreaks of poorly understood diseases (Harvell et al., 2002;Hughes et al., 2003;Ward and Lafferty, 2004). At present, very little is known about both the molecular processes that underpin the establishment and maintenance of the symbiosis, or coral immune responses to pathogens. Consequently, it is fundamental to determine the mechanisms involved in pathogen and symbiont recognition.

Corals have a simple body plan consisting of only two true tissue layers and no organs ( Fig. 1). Depending on the stage of development (developing or adult coral) these tissues are referred to as the ectoderm/epithelium and the endoderm/gastroderm interlined by the mesoglea. The symbionts Symbiodinium reside mainly in gastrodermal areas located between gut and outer epithelium (barrier to external marine environment) in the oral end of the coral (indicated (a) in Fig. 1) and less frequently in gastrodermal areas between gut and skeleton (aboral areas) ( Fig. 1b). Nematocysts are present in the epithelium in the oral end ( Fig. 1a), but not in the calicoblastic epithelium (Fig. 1b). In the coral symbiosis, the eukaryote symbiont (Symbiodinium) is surrounded by a host-derived membrane (symbiosome) and contributes to the host's energy requirements through translocation of photosynthetically fixed carbon (Falkowski et al., 1984;Muscatine et al., 1984;Yellowlees et al., 2008). The majority of host corals only associate with specific genetic clades or sub-clades of Symbiodinium (e.g. (LaJeunesse, 2005)), suggesting the presence of a well-developed symbiont recognition system and leading to corals being portrayed as a model organism for symbiotic interactions . Symbiodinium can be either maternally inherited (vertical transmission) or obtained from the environment (horizontal transmission) through phagocytosis by coral tissues (Trench, 1987;Fig. 1. Schematic representation of adult reef-building coral tissues and structures. Corals have only two true tissue layers, the ectoderm/epithelium and the endoderm/gastroderm interlined by the mesoglea, and no organs. Symbiodinium reside mainly in gastrodermal areas between gut and outer epithelium in the oral end of the coral (a) and less frequently in gastrodermal areas between gut and skeleton (aboral areas) (b). Nematocysts are present in the epithelium at the oral end (a), but not in the calicoblastic epithelium (b). Schwarz et al., 1999;van Oppen, 2001;Coffroth et al., 2006;Marlow and Martindale, 2007). Those corals that obtain their symbionts horizontally may phagocytose several Symbiodinium strains along with food particles; however the resulting phagosome then avoids lysosome fusion by unknown means. Appropriate strains then multiply in phagosomes, establishing a stable symbiosis, whilst unsuitable strains are actively removed through cellular processes (Dunn and Weis, 2009). Symbiodinium is an alveolate (Zhang et al., 2005), as are many intracellular pathogens, suggesting that analogous mechanisms may underlie the utilization of host immune mechanisms by these eukaryotic pathogens and symbionts for entering the tissues. This hypothesis predicts that mechanisms of self/non-self-recognition have been co-opted into the symbiont establishment process (Weis et al., 2008;Kvennefors et al., 2008).

Recently it was shown that corals and other cnidarians contain a surprisingly high degree of genetic complexity (Kortschak et al., 2003;Miller et al., 2005;Putnam et al., 2007;, and homologs of many proteins involved in immunity in vertebrates are present in cnidarians, suggesting ancient origins of these molecules in ancestral animals (Miller et al., 2007). The primary function of the innate immune system is to recognize specific patterns on non-self-entities (Janeway and Medzhitov, 2002;Medzhitov and Janeway, 2002). These patterns are referred to as pathogen associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) (Janeway and Medzhitov, 2002), or microbe associated molecular patterns (MAMPs), and some of the best studied of these are microbial cell wall components such as lipopolysaccharide (LPS), peptidoglycan and mannan. These and other MAMPs are recognized by proteins referred to as pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) or pattern recognition proteins (PRPs) and this class of molecules includes both membrane bound proteins such as the Toll-like receptors and soluble proteins such as lectins. We recently characterised a mannose binding lectin from the coral Acropora millepora that is related to the vertebrate collectins, including mannose binding lectin (MBL) and surfactant protein A (SP-A), as well as to an ancestral ascidian MBL-like protein (Kvennefors et al., 2008). In vertebrates, SP-A can function as an opsonin for phagocytosis (Madan et al., 1997) and MBL is an important activator of many immune functions, including that of complement via the lectin-complement pathway (Takahashi et al., 2006). The coral lectin, known as Millectin, was shown to bind both bacteria and Symbiodinium in vitro, suggesting roles for the protein in both immunity and symbiont recruitment (Kvennefors et al., 2008). The detection of a high degree of sequence variation in the binding region of Millectin implies diversity in the binding repertoire (Kvennefors et al., 2008), perhaps to accommodate diverse target MAMPs.

The complement system is one arm of the vertebrate adaptive immune system, but complement factor C3 (C3) also participates in innate immunity via the opsonisation of foreign cells for phagocytosis and in inflammatory processes (Sahu and Lambris, 2001). The discovery of a vertebrate C3 homolog in the gorgonian coral Swiftia exserta (Dishaw et al., 2005) and similar molecules in other invertebrates (Raftos et al., 2002;Clow et al., 2004;Endo et al., 2006;Castillo et al., 2009) that predate the origins of the adaptive immune system suggests not only ancient origins for this molecule, but also for a prototype complement pathway. The C3 proteins belong to the thiolester-containing protein (TEP) family, which also includes opsonins from insects (Levashina et al., 2001), and sea urchin and horseshoe crab C3 with opsonic capabilities (Smith, 2002;Clow et al., 2004;Zhu et al., 2005;Ariki et al., 2008). In addition, the C3like proteins from ascidians have been implicated in inflammatory responses (Raftos et al., 2003;Raftos et al., 2004). Interestingly, a 'primitive' form of the complement system, in which lectins interact with C3 for direct activation of phagocytosis, has been reported in invertebrates (Zhu et al., 2005;Endo et al., 2006). In ascidians, this opsonisation and activation includes the MBL-like protein (referred to as GBL; (Sekine et al., 2001)) related to Millectin. Therefore, further investigations to determine the roles in coral immunity of both Millectin and a recently discovered C3-like molecule from A. millepora (C3-Am) (Miller et al., 2007) are warranted.

The complex endosymbiosis between the coral host and Symbiodinium is likely to be regulated by non-self-recognition. Previously, many potential PRRs, including lectins, have been identified through microarray studies of corals (Miller et al., 2007;Schwarz et al., 2008), and lectins have been implicated in phagocytosis of Symbiodinium by the coral (Wood-Charlson et al., 2006). Investigations of PRPs in early immune pathways and their role in symbiosis will improve our understanding of the causes of symbiosis breakdown (bleaching) and disease outbreaks in these basal, but key, animals on coral reefs. Similarly, it will enhance our understanding of early evolutionary traits of innate immune mechanisms. The present study provides insight into the function of potential pattern recognition proteins, Millectin and C3-Am in immunity, symbiosis and host-microbe interactions in the coral model organism A. millepora.

div.head: Sequence alignment of A. millepora C3-like protein
div.p: The previously undescribed full cDNA sequence of a complement C3-like molecule (C3-Am; GenBank accession EF090257) derived from Acropora millepora EST analysis (full sequence provided by D. Miller; partial sequence described by Miller et al. (Miller et al., 2007)) were aligned and compared to previously characterised C3-related proteins by NCBI BLAST server. Translated cDNA sequences of C3 from A. millepora (this study), along with C3 homologs from soft coral (Q8I7P1), a functionally proven C3like protein from horseshoe crab (B6ZH52) and human (P01024) derived from the SWISS PROT database (http://au.expasy.org/) were subsequently aligned in ClustalX (version 1.83) (Thompson et al., 1997) and visualized in the software program Genedoc. Cleavage and functional sites were predicted based on comparisons and alignment with human C3 (P01024). Signal peptide for secretion was predicted using the Signal P Server (Bendtsen et al., 2004).

div.head: Sample collection
div.p: Samples of apparently healthy A. millepora were collected from the Heron Island reef flat (23.4417 • S, 151.9125 • E), southern Great Barrier Reef, Australia, in April 2008. Replicate samples consisted of the outer 4-5 cm of the tip of branches from different colonies, unless stated otherwise. For histology and immunohistochemistry, replicates (n = 4) were collected from the reef flat and immediately fixed in 4% (w/v) paraformaldehyde in sterile phosphate buffered saline (PBS, pH 7.4) for 10 h, and then stored in PBS at 4 • C until processed (Ainsworth et al., 2007). Samples for gene expression studies included; (i) samples directly from the wild (reef flat samples; n = 5); (ii) samples (n = 5) acclimatised in open aquaria (water supply from the reef flat) for 3 weeks; (iii) and samples for immune challenge experiments (transported live to an indoor closed aquaria system) further described below. All samples for gene expression were snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen within seconds of sampling. All samples were kept at −80 • C until processed, when the outer 1-2 cm of the tip was used for RNA extraction. Coral egg and sperm from A. millepora to be used as Symbiodinium-free coral control samples were kindly sampled (snap-frozen upon spawning) by Dr R. Reef and Dr S. Ward during a spawning season (November 2007). Further control samples for gene expression studies consisting of cDNA from laboratory cultures of coral Symbiodinium (Clade C1) were provided by Dr N. Rosic (prepared as described previously ).

div.head: Experimental immune challenges
div.p: One coral colony was divided into replicate fragment branches and acclimated in artificial seawater for 3 weeks. Non-handled baseline expression samples were snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen 30 min prior to the initiation of the experiment (i.e. 30 min prior to injection of the treatment samples). Sterile phosphate (10 mM phosphate) buffered saline (PBS) + 2% NaCl (340 mM), was used as a handling/injection control and also as a dilution buffer for immunostimulants. This buffer has a total osmolarity of 1000 mOsm and pH (pH 7.4) corresponding to the conditions within coral tissues. Immunostimulants (500 l) (LPS from Escherichia coli (L2880 Sigma) 50 g ml −1 and Peptidoglycan from Staphyloccocus (77140 Sigma) 10 g ml −1 , diluted in the dilution buffer were evenly injected into 5 polyps (polypsize of 1-4 mm ) of the coral fragment using a 1 ml syringe fitted with a 26-gauge needle. At 45 min, 6 h and 12 h post-injection, 3 replicate fragments from each treatment were snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80 • C until processed.

div.head: RNA extraction, reverse transcription and quantitative real-time PCR
div.p: Total RNA was isolated using TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen). A small piece of the coral fragment (2 cm ), or equivalent amount of control samples, was crushed in liquid nitrogen and transferred to a 1 ml aliquot of TRIzol reagent. The coral was further disrupted in TRIzol using a handheld homogenizer on maximum speed for 30 s. Total RNA from the remaining slurry was extracted using the manufacturer's protocol, which includes an initial centrifugation step that effectively removes coral skeleton particles. The quality of mRNA was assessed using a 2100 Bioanalyser and RNA Nano Labchip (Agilent Technologies). The quantity of total extracted RNA was determined using a spectrophotometer (Nanodrop ND-1000) at 260 nm. An aliquot of 300 ng of RNA from each prepared sample was converted to cDNA using a Quantitect Reverse Transcription Kit (Qiagen) according to manufacturer's instructions. This kit includes an initial DNAse treatment to remove any contaminating DNA and a final RNAse treatment to remove any residual RNA after conversion. Controls for DNA contamination included mRNA from samples used that were subjected to treatments as according to the Quantitect Reverse Transcription Kit, but with no added reverse transcriptase. For internal reference during quantitative real-time PCR, partial sequences of 2 genes constitutively expressed under experimental conditions, and previously used in gene expression analysis were provided by Dr F. Seneca. These were an unknown EST named Contig1913 (Csaszar et al., 2009) and adenosyl-homocysteinase (AdoHcyase) (Levy et al., 2007). ␤-Actin was also included as a reference gene as it has previously been used in gene expression studies of A. millepora (Levy et al., 2007), and has been shown to be stable and unaffected by varying symbiont contributions in other cnidarians (Rodriguez-Lanetty et al., 2008). Primers for use in quantitative real-time PCR were designed using Primer Express TM v. 2.0 (Applied Biosystems) (Table 1). Test PCR amplifications confirmed the calculated amplicon sizes (70-100 bp) and subsequent melting temperature curves of each amplicon were established. Efficiency of target amplification was optimized by evaluation of four primer concentrations (200, 150, 100 and 50 nM) and series of 2-, 5-and 10-fold dilutions of template cDNA from control and experimental coral samples. Constant cycle threshold (C t ) values were observed at a 200 nM primer concentrations for each of the primer pairs and cDNA dilutions above 10-fold dilutions were shown to produce non-inhibited PCR reactions. Triplicate first strand cDNA aliquots (2 l) from a 20-fold dilution of each sample served as templates for quantitative PCR in 10 l reactions using SYBR ® GREEN PCR Master Mix (Applied Biosystems) and 200 nM of each specific primer in a ABI 7900HT thermocycler (Applied Biosystems). PCR conditions were as follows; initial denaturation (95 • C, 10 min), 45 cycles of a denaturation step (95 • C, 15 s) and hybridisation-elongation step (60 • C, 1 min), where a subsequent melting temperature curve of the amplicon was also performed. Target genes were normalized against expression of internal control genes (reference) in the corresponding sample using the formula: 2 −(C t target−C t reference) , with the cycle threshold (C t ) set at 0.12 for all genes.

In validating the use of the internal control genes, C t values were determined using triplicate samples and were found not to vary significantly between treatments. Controls using cDNA from coral gametes devoid of Symbiodinium sourced from A. millepora (horizontal acquisition; (Trench, 1987;van Oppen, 2001)) and equal amounts of template cDNA from cultured Symbiodinium confirmed that the primers used in quantitative PCR were coral host specific. The expression of target genes is presented relative to ␤-actin, but gene expression was analysed relative to each of the internal control genes independently and showed consistent patterns of up-or down-regulation in different sample groups.

div.head: Statistical analyses
div.p: Differences in relative gene expression were analysed using the software package Statistica v. 8, and were considered significant when P < 0.05. A series of one-way analysis of variance (ANOVAs) were performed to test differences in gene expression. Post hoc tests were performed using Fisher LSD test. Normality and homogeneity of variance was assessed using Bartlett's test of equal variances and residual plots. Log and square root transformations of data were used to ensure homogeneity of variance. For comparisons of expression of reference genes between treatments, C t values were log and square root transformed, yet the data still failed Bartlett's test and the non-parametric Kruskal-Wallis test was used in this specific analysis. Results are presented as the mean ± standard error.

div.head: SDS-PAGE gels and western blots
div.p: For sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) and Western blots, tissues from frozen field corals were removed using a sterile scalpel on ice and 0.5 mM phenylmethyl sulfonyl fluoride (PMSF), and 1 mg ml −1 each of pepstatin and leupeptin were added to the slurry. An aliquot of this slurry was further homogenized using a hand held homogenizer as described above and coral algal symbionts removed by centrifugation at 1500 × g for 10 min at 4 • C. Resulting coral protein extracts with or without symbionts were each dialyzed with TS buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl, 150 mM NaCl, pH 7.4) to remove excess salts that could interfere with the SDS-PAGE and Western blots. Protein concentrations were determined using a Bradford assay (Sigma). SDS-PAGE was performed in a Hoeffer SE260 electrophoresis unit (GE Healthcare), where proteins were separated in discontinuous gels comprising 12% acrylamide resolving gels overlaid with 4% acrylamide stacking gels. Coral proteins (20 g) were separated under reducing conditions (5% mercaptoethanol, 6 min at 99 • C), or under highly reducing conditions (15% mercaptoethanol, 10 min at 99 • C) where specified. Additional controls consisting of standard maintained laboratory cultures of Symbiodinium (clade C1) were prepared using a 10 ml aliquot of culture, centrifuged at 1500 × g for 3 min and thereafter removing the supernatant in order to achieve a dense suspension with optical density at 600 nm (OD 600 = 5). The culture was then homogenized with glass beads (BIO101) using a MagnaLyser bead mill (Roche Diagnostics) at 4500 rpm for 2 min. An aliquot (10 l) of this suspension was loaded onto the SDS-PAGE gels for subsequent Western blots as a control for any potential cross-reacting epitopes of dinoflagellate origin. Molecular weights of coral proteins were estimated by comparison with Precision plus prestained standards (BioRad).

Antibodies against coral C3 and Millectin were raised commercially (GenScript Corp., USA) utilizing KLH conjugated peptides (C3 -KVEPEDLPDPTSVDC) (Millectin -KINSKEENNFC) in mouse and rabbit, respectively. For Western blots, SDS-PAGE gels were blotted onto a PDVF membrane (Immobilon P, Millipore) in Towbin buffer (0.025 M Tris-HCl, 0.192 M glycine, 20% methanol) using a semi-dry blotting apparatus (Semi-Phor TE70, GE Healthcare). Blotted membranes were blocked in 2% BSA in Tris buffered saline containing 0.05% Tween 20 (TBST) at 4 • C overnight, followed by washes and incubated in primary antibody for 2 h at room temperature (rabbit anti-Millectin antibody and rabbit preserum from corresponding animal 1:16,000) (mouse anti-C3 and mouse pre-serum 1:1000). All antibodies were consistently diluted in blocking buffer (2% BSA in TBST). After washes, secondary antibodies alkaline phosphatase (AP)-conjugated anti-rabbit IgG (A-9919 Sigma) and AP-conjugated anti-mouse IgG antibodies (A-3562 Sigma) diluted 1:30,000 were incubated for 1 h at room temperature. Membranes were washed copiously in TBST then colour was developed using 1

Step TM NBT/BCIP (Pierce) according to manufacturer's instructions. Controls included pre-immune serum from the animal from which the corresponding antibody was raised, and was used in Western blots at the same dilutions as for the corresponding antibody.

div.head: Immunohistochemistry
div.p: Samples for immunohistochemistry were decalcified in 20% (w/v) EDTA (pH 8) as described previously (Ainsworth et al., 2007) and processed for paraffin wax embedding by standard histology protocol including stepwise dehydration through 70%, 80%, 95% and 100% ethanol, followed by 3× 1 h cycles of paraffin then fully embedded in paraffin. Serial sections of 5 m were cut with a microtome (Cut4060, MicroTec) and transferred onto SuperFrost PLUS slides (Menzel-Glaser), allowed to dry overnight and dewaxed prior use in staining procedures. Immunohistochemistry was primarily performed using secondary horseradish peroxidase (HRP) conjugated anti-rabbit IgG antibody (P0399 Dako, Denmark) for Millectin and alkaline phosphatase (AP)-conjugated antibodies for C3 (A-3562 Sigma). Staining with secondary AP-conjugated antibody (A-9919 Sigma) and HRP-conjugated antibody (A9044 Sigma) for Millectin and C3, respectively, was also conducted to further confirm the staining patterns.

Dewaxed slides were blocked in 2% BSA in TBST. Following washes, the slides were incubated in primary antibody (anti-Millectin or the corresponding preserum, 1:500; or anti-C3 or the corresponding preserum, 1:250) for 4 h at room temperature. After washes, secondary antibodies (anti-rabbit HRP and AP, 1:300; antimouse HRP 1:200, anti-mouse AP 1:100, in TBST) were incubated for 1 h at room temperature. Detection of secondary antibody AP conjugate used 1 Step TM NBT/BCIP (Pierce) following quenching of endogenous phosphatase activity with 1 mM levamisol (46944 Sigma), whilst HRP-conjugated antibody was visualized with 3,3diaminobenzidine (DAB) tablets including urea hydrogen peroxide (SIGMAFAST TM , D4418, Sigma). All control slides with pre-immune serum were developed precisely as for corresponding primary antibodies. Additional controls utilizing secondary antibodies only, or stain only, were also performed. Further controls utilizing fetal bovine serum albumin and goat serum (G9023, Sigma) as blocking buffer for immunohistochemistry were also performed. After staining, slides were permanently mounted using DPX neutral mounting medium (Ajax Finechem) and observed under bright-field light microscopy with an Olympus BX41 microscope fitted with a DP-70 digital camera.

div.head: Sequence analysis of coral C3-like protein
div.p: BLASTp analysis of C3-Am revealed high sequence identity with other cnidarian C3-like proteins as well as those from the lancelet and horseshoe crab (accession numbers B9X079-81, Q969A4, B6ZH52, Q5NKN5; E-value by BLAST E = 0), and high similarity with the corresponding vertebrate proteins (e.g. human C3, P01024; E = 2e −150 ). Comparison of the A. millepora protein with the C3 sequences from soft coral, horseshoe crab and man implied that the basic domain structure is highly conserved (Fig. 2). As in the case of other cnidarian C3-like proteins (Dishaw et al., 2005;Kimura et al., 2009), sites required for activation and function of the protein were conserved in the A. millepora protein, including the cleavage site for release of the alpha and beta chains, the C3a anaphylatoxin region, catalytic histidine residue and thioester site (Fig. 2). A predicted signal peptide for secretion, in common with other C3 proteins, was also observed (Fig. 2).

div.head: Relative gene expression analysis
div.p: A clear difference was observed between C3-Am and Millectin when basal expression levels of these two genes were compared between reef samples and corals from five different coral colonies Fig. 3. Gene expression levels in coral samples from the reef and after acclimation in aquaria. Bars indicate expression levels (2 −(Ct target−Ct reference) ) of C3-Am and Millectin relative to the internal reference gene ␤-actin in coral samples from the reef (n = 5) and after acclimation in aquaria (n = 5). Data represent means ± standard errors and asterisk show significant differences (*P < 0.001) between aquaria and reef samples in the case of Millectin. that had been acclimated to aquarium conditions (Fig. 3). Whereas C3-Am was expressed at relatively low (and not significantly different) levels in reef and aquarium-acclimated samples, Millectin expression was consistently high in reef samples but significantly lower in aquarium-acclimated samples (P < 0.001; Fig. 3).

Changes in the expression of the Millectin and C3-Am genes in response to immunogens was monitored in individual replicate samples derived from one mother colony. This approach was chosen to minimize confounding variability in baseline gene expression resulting from different genetic backgrounds as observed in previous studies (Bay et al., 2009a;Bay et al., 2009b;Seneca et al., 2009), and allows for the detection of a subtle molecular mechanism or pathway (by significant up-or downregulation) within a colonial organism. Differential gene expression was measured following injection of control phosphate buffered saline (PBS), or one of two defined immunogens: peptidoglycan or lipopolysaccharide (LPS), cell wall components of Gram positive and Gram negative bacteria, respectively. Control injections of PBS had a significant effect on C3-Am expression (baseline vs. PBS 720 min, P < 0.05) and the effect was time dependent (Fig. 4a), indicating that the physical process of injection and injury induced C3 expression. This high background in injection controls, and high levels of variation between replicates meant that no significant effects could be detected in C3 expression following treatment with immunogens ( Fig. 4a).

In contrast to C3-Am, Millectin was not up-regulated following injection with PBS, and both immunogens stimulated Millectin expression, but with different kinetics. In both cases, the upregulation observed was statistically significant; Millectin gene expression was up-regulated following treatment with either 25 g LPS (baseline vs. LPS 45 min and 360 min, P < 0.05) or 5 g peptidoglycan (PEP) (baseline vs. PEP 360 and 720 min, P < 0.05) (Fig. 4b).

Following injection with LPS, Millectin expression showed a significant increase in expression at 45 min and then declined over time, returning to pre-challenge levels after 720 min. In contrast, following injection of peptidoglycan, Millectin expression gradually increased with time with maximal expression at 720 min (Fig. 4b).

div.head: Antibody specificity of coral anti-C3-Am and anti-Millectin
div.p: Antibodies were raised against synthetic peptides designed on the basis of the predicted amino acid sequences of the A. millepora C3 and Millectin proteins. The specificity of the antibodies for the synthesized peptides was confirmed by ELISA by the manufacturer and demonstrated to be both specific and titratable. The antibody specificity was further confirmed by probing Western blots of reduced coral protein extracts and homogenates of cul- . The baseline represents five (untreated) replicate coral fragments that were sampled 30 min prior to commencing the injections with immunostimulants. PBS: control (injected with phosphate buffered saline). LPS: injected with 25 g lipopolysaccharide. PEP: injected with 5 g peptidoglycan. Within each challenge group, triplicate samples were used for each timepoint. Data represent means ± standard errors and asterisks indicate significant differences (*P < 0.05) above baseline expression levels. C3-Am was significantly up-regulated in PBS-injected samples after 720 min, while Millectin was significantly up-regulated after injection with LPS at 45 and 360 min, and after injection with peptidoglycan at 360 and 720 min.

tured Symbiodinium. Bands corresponding to the expected sizes of C3-Am and Millectin were observed in the coral protein extracts for both antibodies, while no bands were observed when blots were probed with pre-immune serum from the animals in which the antibodies were raised (Fig. 5). No significant staining was observed when blots of cultured Symbiodinium were probed with either of the primary antibodies (Fig. 5).

Coral homogenates probed with the anti-Millectin antibody revealed dominant bands with approximate relative mobility (M R ) in the ∼23 and ∼70 kDa regions on blots from gels run under on strongly reducing conditions. The ∼23 and ∼70 kDa bands correspond to the expected sizes of the monomeric and a previously reported trimeric (Kvennefors et al., 2008) form of the Millectin protein, respectively. The stability of the trimeric form of Millectin under strongly reducing conditions is consistent with previous observations of inability to reduce multimeric forms of lectins found in mucosal surfaces, including that of the Millectin relatives SP-A and SP-D (Axelsson et al., 1998;Strong et al., 1998;van Eijk et al., 2004;Madan et al., 2001;Sorensen et al., 2009).

When Western blots of whole coral extracts were probed with anti-C3-Am antibody, a distinct but faint band was observed at approximately 80 kDa, corresponding to the expected size of the monomeric C3 ␤-chain (Raftos et al., 2002;Raftos et al., 2004). Interestingly, C3 staining was not detected in coral samples that had been centrifuged (to remove symbionts) prior to protein extraction ( Fig. 5), suggesting that the C3 protein is normally associated with material lost during centrifugation. Control samples from laboratory cultured Symbiodinium showed no binding of antibody.

div.head: Immunohistochemistry
div.p: When histology sections of healthy coral collected from the reef flat were probed with anti-C3-Am antibodies, immunostaining was evident in gastrodermal cells in close association with Symbiodinium, as well as in the cytoplasm and outer lining of epithelial cells. However, all epithelial cells were not stained. Areas that showed epithelial staining were often accompanied by staining in the mesoglea (for tissue structures see Figs. 1 and 6a) ( Fig. 6g and h), perhaps indicating a targeted C3 release response in specific areas of the epithelia. Probing sections with the anti-Millectin antibody revealed intense staining associated with nematocysts in the coral epithelium ( Fig. 6b and d). Immunostaining for Millectin was also observed coating Symbiodinium cells residing in the gastroderm, and some compartments in the gastroderm lining of the gut and skeleton also stained intensely (Fig. 6b and c). No staining was observed in pre-immune serum controls for either of the primary antibodies ( Fig. 6e and f) or when primary antibody was omitted (data not shown). Patterns of staining were identical irrespective of whether AP or HRP-conjugated secondary antibodies were employed, corroborating the specificity of the results.

div.head: Expression of Millectin and C3-Am in response to immune stimulation and injury
div.p: To our knowledge, this study is the first to localize expression of proteins involved in the immunity of corals and demonstrate how they respond to immune challenges. In higher animals, many immune-related genes are induced in response to MAMPs, via signaling cascades, following recognition by Toll-like receptors and other PRPs. In A. millepora, both LPS and peptidoglycan upregulated the putative PRP, the C-type lectin Millectin (Kvennefors et al., 2008), suggesting a function in response to microbial challenge. However, the kinetics of the Millectin induction differed between MAMPs. The response to LPS was short and fast, while the response to peptidoglycan was slower, suggesting that activation may occur by two distinct pathways. In other animals, secreted PRP lectins, similar to Millectin, function as acute phase proteins that are immediately induced in response to infection or invasion. The rapid response to LPS treatment is consistent with an acute phase protein role for Millectin in the coral.

The nature of the response to immune stimuli was more difficult to interpret in the case of C3-Am, as this gene was significantly upregulated by control (PBS) injections. While it cannot be completely excluded that bacteria from the mucus may have entered the tissues during the injection process resulting in the observed response for C3-Am, the lack of response to the same control procedure by Millectin (that clearly responds to both LPS and peptidoglycan) indicates that this is not the case. In addition, no change of expression in response to injection of the buffer was recorded in additional immune molecules investigated (unpublished data). Hence, we suggest that C3-Am expression may be regulated in response to physical trauma, perhaps providing a first line of defense in mediating inflammatory processes following tissue damage (Raftos et al., 2003;Raftos et al., 2004). A similar role has been proposed in humans, where C3 and the proteins required for its activation are present in the epidermis and keratinocytes (Dovezenski et al., 1992). Moreover, complement factors may function in wound healing and tissue regeneration in the newt Notophthalmus viridescens, as C3 and C5 are expressed during limb and lens regeneration, but not in undamaged tissue (Kimura et al., 2003). Although the role of C3 in the wound repair process remains to be elucidated, numerous studies have reported C3 activation following injury to various tissues including the epidermis, muscle and the nervous system (Dovezenski et al., 1992;Bellander et al., 2001;Kimura et al., 2003;Ohlsson et al., 2003;Ganter et al., 2007). The mechanism of C3 activation in response to tissue trauma in coral therefore requires further investigation.

Comparisons of the expression levels of C3-Am and Millectin between field samples and lab acclimated corals serves as a cautionary note on interpretation of results from aquarium studies. In lab acclimated corals, un-induced Millectin expression levels were very low, whereas in field samples the gene was expressed at a similar (moderately high) level to the constitutively expressed gene ␤-actin, suggesting a housekeeping role for this protein in the coral. The down-regulation of Millectin in this particular case proved useful as we were able to more effectively demonstrate the response to MAMPs by reducing the background level against which responses to immune challenges are observed. However, differing studies, especially those involving disease transmission should take such changes into account when extrapolating results from studies carried out in aquaria to the field situation. There are several possible explanations for the decreased expression of Millectin observed in aquarium-acclimated coral including (but not limited to): reduced levels of disturbances such as grazing (from microorganisms in grazers mouths); or redirection of energy away , (e and f) Controls in which pre-immune serum was substituted for either anti-Millectin (e) or anti-C3-Am (f), showed no staining. (g and h) Anti-C3-Am primary antibody detected with AP-conjugated secondary antibody, showing staining within gastrodermal cells in close proximity to Symbiodinium as well as in some areas of the epithelium (cytoplasm and lining of epithelial cells) and mesoglea (extracellular tissue that participate in transport of material between cells).
from Millectin expression and towards more immediate survival functions in the corals following the trauma resulting from collection.

div.head: Localization of C3-Am and Millectin suggest roles in both immunity and symbiosis
div.p: In A. millepora, and in many other coral species, the symbiotic Symbiodinium are not maternally transferred and must be acquired from the environment at each generation (Coffroth et al., 2006). One outstanding fundamental question in coral biology is how the symbionts become established and are able to persist in host tissue. Two different routes of uptake have been suggested: symbionts may either directly enter endodermal cells via the oral pore in early development (Schwarz et al., 1999), or initially enter via the ectoderm and subsequently be shunted into the endoderm/gastroderm (Marlow and Martindale, 2007). As Symbiodinium are related to intracellular pathogens that utilize host immune mechanisms to enter the tissues, and both pathogens and symbionts would be recognized by non-self-recognition molecules (i.e. PRPs), it is likely that some of the molecules within the broad repertoire of putative cnidarian PRRs or PRPs (Miller et al., 2007;Schwarz et al., 2008) are not only involved in immunity, but perhaps also, or even exclusively, involved in host/symbiont interactions.

C3 is expressed in endodermal cells during the early development of A. millepora (Miller et al., 2007) and other cnidarians (Kimura et al., 2009). Consistent with the early expression observed in the endoderm, the C3-Am was detected in parts of the adult coral gastroderm (endoderm). While the pattern of staining suggested that C3 was most abundant in parts of the gastroderm closely associated with Symbiodinium, some coral C3 appears to also be associated with the mesoglea and areas of ectoderm/epithelium. In vertebrates, C3 circulates in the plasma or blood, but the localization of C3 in invertebrates is different. For example, in a pattern reminiscent of that seen in the coral, aggregates of C3 protein have been observed in the epithelia of the bobtail squid Euprymna scolopes (Castillo et al., 2009). The localization of C3-Am in the epithelia that represents the barrier towards the external marine environment, along with the observed up-regulation in response to injury, supports the hypothesis of a role for this protein in coral immunity in response to invasion associated with tissue traumas. Several other invertebrate C3 proteins have the functional characteristics of opsonins (Smith, 2002;Clow et al., 2004;Zhu et al., 2005;Ariki et al., 2008) and, given the high sequence similarity and conserved structure of activation sites of the coral protein with these, it is likely that coral C3 can also function as an opsonin. As C3-Am staining was consistently observed in areas of the gastroderm closely associated with Symbiodinium, it may be that C3 participates in opsonisation of the symbionts to be phagocytosed and incorporated into the coral cell. However, the staining patterns observed for C3 are less clear than those observed for Millectin. Nonetheless, these results provide a framework for future research into the functional roles of coral C3 in opsonisation and symbiont interaction.

Immunohistochemistry using specific anti-Millectin antibody to probe sections of coral sampled from the reef resulted in dense staining of nematocysts (capsules with an inverted tubule and associated operculum for prey capture or colony defense (Mariscal, 1974;Westfall, 1966)) in the epithelia and around Symbiodinium. Dense rounded aggregates (putative vesicles) lining the gastroderm directly adjacent to the lining of the gut in both oral (facing the mouth and external environment) and aboral (lining the skeleton) tissue were also observed. The dense immunostaining is consistent with the high levels of Millectin gene expression in reef samples detected by quantitative PCR in the current study. Localization of the protein to both the nematocysts and the gastroderm would ensure that pathogens are exposed to Millectin regardless of how they enter the coral. Given the agglutination capabilities of bacteria by Millectin, such exposure would ensure an effective means of inhibiting further colonization of the tissues (Kvennefors et al., 2008). Millectin has previously been shown to contain a signal peptide for secretion. This signal peptide, and an additional 30 amino acids of the N-terminal sequence, appears to be cleaved in activated proteins (protein with carbohydrate-binding capabilities) (Kvennefors et al., 2008). The sizes detected on Western blots in the present study, indicate that a large proportion of the Millectin in coral tissue retains the signal sequence and is uncleaved occurring as the full length inactive protein. Unconventional secretion of proteins, bypassing the Golgi and thus leaving signal peptides intact, may be more common than previously thought (Nickel and Rabouille, 2009), therefore it is possible that Millectin is secreted in an uncleaved state and, subsequent to release the lectin may be cleaved for activation, hence avoiding damage of host tissues by the activated protein. The immunohistochemistry data indicates that Millectin is secreted into the vacuole of the nematocysts and packaged into transport vesicles that may fuse with the plasma membrane of the gastroderm for the contents to be secreted in response to invasion. It is hypothesized that the protein resides in these vesicles in un-activated (uncleaved) form, until stimulated nematocysts discharge explosively and release their contents (Holstein and Tardent, 1984), or the gastroderm vacuoles fuse with a potential invader/symbiont through the plasma membrane. This hypothesis is consistent with previous reports that mechanical stimuli induce immediate release of antimicrobial proteins from corals (Geffen and Rosenberg, 2005) and that glycoproteins with cytotoxic activity are present in cnidarian nematocysts (Bernheimer and Avigad, 1976;Helmholz et al., 2008). Although the identities of these proteins are unknown, the nematocyst proteins were isolated using lectin-affinity methods and are similar in molecular mass to Millectin (Helmholz et al., 2008). Localization of Millectin in the lining of the gastroderm may provide a first line of defense against pathogens such as endolithic algae that attempt to penetrate the tissues lining the skeleton, where no nematocysts are present (Yarden et al., 2007).

The pattern of staining associated with Symbiodinium inside coral tissues is consistent with previous reports that Millectin binds to the surface of symbionts in vitro (Kvennefors et al., 2008). Recently, a lectin (PdC-Lectin) from the coral Pocillopora damicornis was also observed to coat Symbiodinium in vivo (Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2009) and it is likely that several proteins (perhaps several lectins) are involved in the symbiosis process. An analogous situation to that of the staining pattern in the present study is seen in the soft coral Sinularia lochmodes, where the galactose-binding lectin SLL2 is abundant in nematocysts and binds to a dinoflagellate symbiont (Jimbo et al., 2000;Jimbo et al., 2005). Intriguingly, the SLL2 protein induced transformation of the free-living dinoflagellate to a stage appropriate for symbiosis (Koike et al., 2004), suggesting that Millectin could have a similar function in Acropora spp. Lectins are critical for phagocytosis of Symbiodinium by the coral (Wood-Charlson et al., 2006) and the phylogenetic position, structure and observed pattern recognition capabilities of Millectin make it probable that this protein act as an opsonin during phagocytosis of symbionts. While the precise mechanisms of these interactions require investigation, the results presented here specifically implicate Millectin not only in coral immune responses, but also in host/symbiont interactions.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Our findings indicate that innate immune functions of mannose binding lectin and complement C3 arose early in evolution, and have been conserved in both invertebrates and vertebrates. The coral C3 protein is expressed in response to trauma and injury, and similarity at the level of sequence homology and predicted structure implies a potential function as an opsonin that could be relevant to both immunity and symbiosis. However, the role of the C3 protein in response to invaders and symbionts is, as yet, unclear. The mannose binding lectin Millectin not only binds to symbionts in vitro, but immunocytochemistry implies a similar association in vivo. In addition to an apparent role in symbiosis, Millectin expression is up-regulated in response to immunogens which, along with observed immunostaining patterns and previous observations of agglutination capabilities, suggests a further role in immunity. These results are consistent with the hypothesis that the pattern recognition properties of Millectin have been coopted from an ancient innate immune system to a role in symbiosis; as symbiosis and parasitism are often regarded as two extremes of the same phenomenon, the involvement of some proteins in both is perhaps to be expected.

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Multiple sequence alignment of C3 proteins. Alignment of translated Acropora millepora C3-like protein (C3-Am; accession EF090257) to complement C3 proteins from Swiftia exserta (SwC3; Q817P1), Tachypleus tridentatus (TtC3; B6ZH52) and human (HuC3; P01024). Shading indicates homology (black 80-100%, grey 60-80%). Boxed areas with arrowheads indicate conserved functional processing sites. Underlined regions indicate the predicted (C3-Am) and known (HuC3) signal peptide sequences. The part of the C3-Am sequence indicted by a boxed area with an asterisk corresponds to the peptide used for antibody production.

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: Changes in coral gene expression following challenge with immunostimulants. Bars indicate levels of expression (2 −(Ct target−Ct reference) ) of coral C3 (a) and Millectin (b) relative to the internal reference gene ␤-actin. Treatments and time points in (a) are as indicated in (b)

figure.head: Fig. 5 .
figure.figDesc: Western blots demonstrating the specificity of antibodies raised to Millectin and to C3-Am. (a) Lane 1: coral protein extracts separated under strongly reducing conditions, probed with anti-Millectin antibody, indicating two bands with relative mobility (MR) of ∼23 and ∼70 kDa, corresponding to monomeric and trimeric(Kvennefors et al., 2008) forms of Millectin as previously reported. Lane 2: coral protein extracts separated under strongly reducing conditions, probed with corresponding pre-immune serum (negative control). Lane 3: cultured Symbiodinium under reducing conditions probed with the anti-Millectin antibody (control for nonspecific Symbiodinium cross-reaction). (b) Lane 1: coral protein extracts without symbionts separated under reducing conditions probed with anti-C3-Am antibody showing no bands. Lane 2: coral protein extracts with symbionts separated under reducing conditions probed with anti-C3-Am antibody. A band with MR ∼ 80 kDa is indicated that corresponds to the expected size of the monomeric C3 ␤ chain. Lane 3: coral protein extracts separated under reducing conditions probed with corresponding pre-immune serum (negative control). Lane 4: cultured Symbiodinium under reducing conditions probed with the anti-C3 antibody (control for non-specific Symbiodinium cross-reaction). Neither lanes containing controls displayed any cross-reacting immunostaining in either (a) or (b). Blots were visualized utilizing alkaline phosphatase-conjugated secondary antibodies and developed with 1 Step TM NBT/BCIP.

figure.head: Fig. 6 .
figure.figDesc: Immunohistochemical staining of Acropora millepora tissue sections probed with anti-Millectin and C3-Am antibodies. (a-h) Histological sections of adult coral showing the different tissue structures of gastroderm (Ga), mesoglea (M), epithelia (Ep) and the specific structures Symbiodinium (Sym), nematocysts (Nem) and dense aggregates (putative vesicles) (Da). Black arrows indicate specific structures and red arrows indicate immunostaining of specific structures, whilst red arrowheads indicate general immunostaining in tissues (e.g. not observed discretely associated with specific subcellular structures such as cytoplasm and extracellular spaces (mesoglea)). Coral sections are shown after staining with: (a) haematoxylin, to act as a reference for structural detail, (b-d) anti-Millectin primary antibody detected with HRP-conjugated secondary antibody showing immunostaining of nematocysts, in regions surrounding Symbiodinium cells as well as dense aggregates (putative vesicles)

The authors would like to thank Professor David Miller at the James Cook University for providing the full length sequence of A. millepora C3 prior to submission, use of internal reference genes and for useful comments and suggestions whilst drafting the manuscript. We thank Bob Simpson and Dr Nela Rosic at The University of Queensland for technical assistance in qRT-PCR equipment and optimization, and supplying Symbiodinium cDNA and cultures, respectively. We further thank Francois Seneca and Yvonne Weiss at the James Cook University for aiding in the selection of reference genes for qRT-PCR, and informative discussions regarding coral immune challenge models, respectively.
